title: What would happen if we discovered ancient technology 1000 years ahead of what we have today? - Quora

response.answer_text: Quimbaya Airplane  These existed between 1000 b.c. to 1000 a.d. The Wright bros. discovered/re-discovered flight around 1903. These were aerodynamically sound so much so that replicas were able to fly without any problems. The natives back then didn’t understand flying tech. It was thousands of years too early for them to even conceive the possibility of flight. But today, if we still can discover an ancient technology 1000 years ahead of us, we wouldn’t be so surprised & we will be able to comprehend it. With the spread of ideas and modern futuristic concepts through Hollywood movies, we would just marvel at the sight of them rather than treat it like magic. It just means that Earth’s history is much longer and more complex than what our historians has made out of it. ADDITION: When you think about the past and the people living 1000-2000 years ago, everyone would go with the “animals”, “insects” theory. Most figurines can be easily represented by what you want to see, similar to local animals & insects. BUT there are a couple of oddities in the bunch. In 1954 the government of Colombia sent part of its collection of ancient gold artifacts on a U. S. tour. Emmanuel Staubs, one of America's leading jewelers, was commissioned to cast reproductions of six of the objects. Fifteen years later one was given to biologist-zoologist Ivan T. Sanderson for analysis. After a thorough examination and consulting a number of experts, Sanderson's mind-boggling conclusion was that the object is a model of a high-speed aircraft at least a thousand years old.  Both Sanderson and Dr. Arthur Poyslee of the Aeronautical Institute of New York concluded it did not represent any known winged animal. In fact, the little artifact appears more mechanical than biological. For example, the front wings are delta-shaped and rigidly straight edged, very un-animal-like. If it’s a thousand years ahead of where we are now it’s probably incomprehensible as to function and operation. Whatever power source it had is almost certainly exhausted and beyond our ability to revive or even replace (think about trying to provide the right amount, type, and cleanliness of electrical power to run your notebook computer with a Baghdad Battery array (pottery with vinegar, a copper and lead rod, no controls, trickle charge.) As we’re seeing with the Internet of Things, it would almost certainly rely on wireless communication with databases, sensors, other devices, etc. and of course now be cut off from all of this (like a cell phone too far from any cell transmission tower.) At a thousand years buried it’s labeling, attachments, controls may no longer be visible or workable (probably projected touch screen or even linked to the user’s brain wirelessly), and there have likely been internal parts failures from time, dust, water, insects, freezing, etc. . So to us it’s a “thingamajiggy” and unlikely to be sent to the right lab with the right scientists to look at it, instead going in a never to be reopened storage box with the thousnds of other artifacts from a dig that aren’t a high enough priority for further testing or even display. Then it goes into the basement storage at the museum or campus buildings for an indefinite time, centuries or at least decades, before it’s re-examined when moving the collection or thrown away to make room for new digs’ finds. If it’s very high technology it would need an engineer familiar with that field (or a team of diverse engineers) to recognize what it might be. There’s an odd archaeological conceit that anything out of place in a dig, i.e. a 1950’s beer can in a 1,500 year old site or a Roman coin on a New England beach was somehow lost there by modern folks and passed somehow through the same layers of soil and rock or has been placed there as a joke or hoax. It’s why time traveling probably has gone on far more than we realize with it’s traces just treated as contaminated sites or hoaxes.

How might we discover it? Imagine if, with the technology of just forty years ago you found an ancient mobile phone and knew not what it was. It is quite improbable that you would understand what the little gold wires might do even if you thought to look at it with a microscope and the silicon chips would be absolutely incomprehensible. That is even if it were preserved particularly well. It is utterly unlikely that you might guess its functions. It is unlikely we would comprehend technologies just a few decades ahead. We have much less chance of even imagining technologies of 1000 years hence, and highly unlikely that there would be any trace left of the fine structure of any circuitry or other engineering. Another point is that we might be certain that the technology was behind us but much less idea that it was ahead of us, or by how much. If we could comprehend it, we would not take 1000 years to develop and adopt it.

If it was technology 1000 years ahead of us we probably wouldn't know what to do with it. That would be like William the Conquerer being given an iPad. However, if it were technology that we could recognise as technology but not fully understand, that would cause confusion, and a lot of excitement. We know this because it has happened. Meet the Antikythera mechanism  This peculiar piece of Ancient Greek technology was uncovered in 1901 and appears to be from about 100 to 250 years BCE. It seems to be a mechanical system for showing the movement of stars. The level of craftsmanship and technology was not seen again until clockmaking some 1500 years later.  It has a mechanism that has been revealed via X-ray and can be described as a proto computer. It seems to be a one-off and remains an enigmatic lure to scientists and historians alike.

I don't really know what we would doing we ever found out some ancient technology being 1000 years ahead of us technologically but what I can say is that the chance of we discovering that is quite too high, if we really work on the correct stuff. I'm not being a racist, but a lot of religious and ancient hindu texts reveal a lot of things that we've just come across. The curvature of space, the distance between the sun and earth, the atom, the gravitational waves, the comets, the newton's laws of motion etc. being a few of these examples. We don't know how did the ancient people come across these things but we surely can now say that it is a lot about rediscovering what already has been discovered ages ago.

Acupuncture is a technology that works- is reputedly up to 4,000 years old, and defies modern explanations. Does that make it ahead it's time? For those who think it works via placebo, or that studies have disproved it by sticking pins in the wrong places and getting the same results, please read the following: https://gumc.georgetown.edu/news/Biologic-Pathways-Affected-by-Acupuncture-in-Rats-Also-Targeted-by-Drugs-in-Humans Unless the rats know about the placebo effect- which would render all medical trials that have used them thus far null and void- you can be sure Acupuncture has some validity. Therefore we have a technology which is 4,000 years old in acupuncture which has yet to be incorporated into western medicine or understood fully but which suggests to me something about human physiology which needs to be explained. In that sense it has yet to be discovered.

We have a description of a steam engine from hellenistic times. They thought it was great fun. However, they never came up with the idea of using it as a power source.The chinese had their gun powder for centuries before it became used in ways we think makes perfect sense.There is a possibility that we have certain "stuff" lying around, which we could use for something, but we just haven't connected the dots yet.

Let us assume this amazing discovery was made by archaeologists and under a secure layer, so there can be little or no doubt about the matter, then the answer to ‘what would happen next’ is obviously to ask these two questions: How did it get there?What can we learn about it?What happens after that would depend on the answers, assuming we learn them.
